div.p: THE ARRAIGNMENT AND CONVICTION OF MERVIN Lord AVDLEY, Earle of Ca≈øtlehaven, (who was by 26. Peers of the Realm found guilty for committing Rapine and Sodomy) at We≈øtmin≈øter, on Monday, April 25. 1631.
By vertue of a Commi≈øsion of Oyer and Terminer, directed to Sir Thomas Coventry, Lord Keeper of the Great Seale of England, Lord high Steward for that day, accompanied with the Iudges.
As al≈øo the beheading of the ≈øaid Earle ≈øhortly after on Tower Hill.
LONDON, Printed for Tho: Thomas. 1642.

div.head: THE ARRAIGNMENT OF The Earle of Ca≈øtlehaven.
div.p: THomas Lord Coventry, Lord Keeper of the Great Seale of England, was for this day Lord high Steward of England, who brought the Commi≈ø≈øion into the Court, and after an Oyez gave it to the Serjeant at Armes, who gave it to Sir Thomas Fan≈øhaw to reade, who reads it, and then the u≈øher of the blacke Rod kneeled downe to my Lord, and pre≈øented him with a white rod. He had ≈øeven great Maces carried before him when hee came into the Court: hee ≈øate in a chaire of State; there attended him a Harald at Armes.

The Judges ≈øate before the Lords on each ≈øide of the table, who≈øe names were,
1. Sir Nicholas Kide, Lord chiefe Ju≈øtice of England.
2. Sir Thomas Richard≈øon, Lord chiefe Ju≈øtice of the Common Pleas.
3. Sir Humphrey Davenport, Lord chiefe Baron.
4. Baron Denham.
5. Judge Iones.
6. Judge Hutton.
7. Judge Whitlocke.
8. Judge Crooke, the Kings learned Coun≈øell.
9. Serjeant Crew.
Ma≈øter Attorney generall.
Ma≈øter Solicitor.
Sir Iohn Finch.
Sir Thomas Fan≈øhaw, Clarke of the Crowne.

After the Commi≈ø≈øion was read, and the ≈øt ‚Ä¢ ffe received by the Lord high Steward, he commanded an Oyez to be made, and after gave licence to all the Peeres of the Realme to put on their hats, and then all the Lords were called by their names, and an≈øwered particularly to them.

Then was the Lieutenant called to bring forth his pri≈øoner, who ≈øate by the Common Pleas, and hee brought him to the barre, with divers of the Guard attending upon him, where he had a place in manner of a pew lined with geat velvet, and the Lieutenant another adjoyning to it: and when he had done his obey≈øance to the Lord Steward, and the re≈øt of the Lords, who al≈øo returned it to the Lord high Steward, ≈øpoke to him to this effect.

p.q:
My Lord Awdley, the King hath under≈øtood both by report, and the verdict of divers Gentlemen of quality, that you ≈øtand impeach ‚Ä¢ d of divers great and haynous crimes; and to try if they be true, he brings you here this day to triall, doing like the Almighty King in the 18. of Gene≈øis, that ≈øent downe to ≈øee whether their ≈øinnes were ≈øo grievous as the cry of them, and Kings on earth can have no better paterne to follow, then the Kings of heaven: the Soveraigne, Gods Vicegerent on earth, hath commanded that you ≈øhould be tried this day: and the de≈øire of his Maje≈øty is your try all ≈øhould be as equall as equity
it ≈øelfe. And becau≈øe the crimes that come this day before you, may in ≈øome breed dete≈øtation, and the per≈øon in others compa≈ø≈øion: fir≈øt lay the≈øe two a≈øide, and let your rea≈øon ≈øway your judgement, and your head your heart. And therefore the≈øe Peeres, who are your Peeres, and who have as noble ju≈øtice in their hearts, as noble blood in their veynes, are this day to try you; therefore if you be innocent, ≈øpeake without feare, and bee ≈øure tho≈øe that accu≈øe you ≈øhall not e≈øcape free. But if you be faulty, I advi≈øe you to give honour to God and the King, and confe≈ø≈øe your fault, for it is no vaine confidence nor ≈øubtilty that can hide the truth; therefore if truth touch you at the heart, and your con≈øcience is a thou≈øand witne≈ø≈øes, and God is greater then both, ≈øtand not again≈øt it; and if you doe not, God will put into the hearts of tho≈øe noble per≈øons to finde it out, and doe that is ju≈øt.

div.p: The Lord Awdley ≈øaid, I have beene a clo≈øe pri≈øoner the≈øe ≈øix months, without friends, and without Coun≈øell, and am but of a weak ≈øpeech at the be≈øt, and therefore I de≈øire to have the liberty of having a Coun≈øell to ≈øpeake for me.

My Lord high Steward ≈øaid, For your impri≈øonment, to you it hath beene a ≈øpeciall favour, for you have had time enough, more then ever any man had that hath beene committed for ≈øuch offences, and more favour then ever any man that came to this bar, and you demand nothing that the law can allow you but you ≈øhall have it, but for your demand I mu≈øt move it to the Judges and they ≈øhall ≈øatisfie you in it, or in any other thing you require.

Then he propounded it to the Judges, who an≈øwered that in criminall cau≈øes coun≈øell is not to be allowed, but for matter of law hee may: Sir Thomas Fan≈øhaw read the Indictment and asked him whether he was guilty or not, Lord Audley an≈øwered, not guilty; Sir Thomas Fan≈øhaw ≈øaid, how wilt thou
be tried? L. Audley an≈øwered, by God and my Peers: The Lord high Steward ≈øaid, the pri≈øoner is indicted of rape and ≈øodomy, by two indictments, and htah pleaded not guilty, and it is my duty to charge you to ≈øtand to the triall of it, and you are to judge of it, as they are to be proved by evidence, and you are to ballance it.

This cau≈øe may cary in it, in ≈øome pity, in others dete≈øtation, both of which ought to be put into the ballance, for a graine on either ≈øide may ≈øway the ≈øcale, but rea≈øon mu≈øt rule your affections, and your heads, your hearts: you are to give an attentive eare, and then weigh equally, that the ≈øcale may leane the right way, and the Judges will a≈ø≈øi≈øt you in point of law, which if you doubt, one may propound it to me, and I to them, or of the pri≈øoner, this your Lord≈øhips are to doe without corporall oath: The law conceiveth you of ≈øuch, that you will do that for ju≈øtice, which others doe for their oath, and therefore admits of no challenge, God direct you to it. Ma≈øter Attorny ≈øaid, my Lord high Steward, and it plea≈øe your Grace, there are two Indictments again≈øt Martin Lord Audley, the fir≈øt for Rape, the ≈øecond for Sodomy, the pri≈øoner is honourable, the crimes di≈øhonorable of which hee is indicted (if it falls out to be true) which is to be left to triall; I dare he bold to ≈øay, never Poet invented, nor Hi≈øtoriographer writ of any ≈øo foule, though Suetonius hath curiou≈øly ≈øet out the vides of ≈øome of the Emperors, which had ab≈øolute power, and that might make them fearele≈ø≈øe of any maner of puni≈øhment, and be≈øides were heathens and knew not God, yet none of them came neere this Lords crime; this is a crime of that rarity in our nation, that wee ≈øeldome know of the like, and the other that we ≈øcar≈øe heare of it, but they are of that pe≈øtilential nature that if they be not puni≈øhed they will draw from heaven heavy judgements upon this Kingdome: I can ≈øpeake with comfort
that all my time, both in his Maje≈øties royall Fathers life, and ≈øince he came to his Crowne, I never had occa≈øion to ≈øpeake in this place again≈øt any Peere of the Realme before now, and God knowes I doe it now with ≈øorrow, and I hope I ≈øhall not have occa≈øion to doe ≈øo much againe; but his Maje≈øty who is the patterne of vertue, not onely as King, but in his per≈øon al≈øo, in whom it is hard to judge whether hee excell mo≈øt in Ju≈øtice or Mercy, but I rather thinke in Mercy, for he would have my Lord Audley the pri≈øoner at Barre heard with as much favour as ≈øuch a crime as this can bee; when he fir≈øt heard it, he gave ≈øtrict accoumpt that the triall ≈øhould bee ≈øearched, that his throne and people ≈øhould be cleared from ≈øo grievous ≈øins, and therefore he was indicted in his owne Countrey, according to the law, by Gentlemen of worth. The Bill is found, and now he is brought to this Barre to be tried by his honourable Peeres, ≈øuch as of who≈øe wi≈øedome and ≈øincerity there can bee no que≈øtion, but to have an honourable hearing. And fir≈øt, I ≈øhall beginne with the indictment of Rape, Bracton tells us of King Athel≈øtons law, before the conque≈øt; if the party were of no cha≈øt life but a whore, yet there may bee a ravi≈øhment, but it is a good plea to ≈øay ≈øhe was his concubine; In an indictment of Rape there is no time of pro≈øecution nece≈ø≈øary, for: nullum tempus occurrit regi, but in ca≈øe of an appeale of Rape, if the woman did not pro≈øecure in convenient time, it will barre her for the crimen ≈øodomiticum, our law had no knowledge of it till 15. H. 8. by which ≈øtatute it was made fellony, and in this there is no more que≈øtion, but onely whether it bee crimen ≈øodomiticum fine penetratione, and the law the 5. of Elizabeth, ≈øets downe in generall words, and there the law doth not di≈øtingi≈øh, neither mu≈øt we: I know you will bee curious how you give the lea≈øt mitigation of ≈øo abhominable a ≈øinne, which brought ≈øuch plagues after it, as we may ≈øee in Gen. 18.
Judges 14. Rom. 1. But my Lords, it ≈øeemed to me ≈øtrange at the fir≈øt, how a noble man of his quality ≈øhould lu≈øt to ≈øuch abhominable ≈øins, but when I found he had given him≈øelfe over to lu≈øt, and find that nemo repente ≈øit pe≈øsimus, and that if men once habit them≈øelves in ill, it is no marvell if they fall into any ≈øinne, and that he was con≈øtant in noreligion, but in the morning would be a Papi≈øt, in the afternoone a Prote≈øtant; I ≈øhall bee bold to give your Grace a rea≈øon why hee became ≈øo ill, he beleeved not God, then what may not a man runne into? but I find things beyond imagination, for I find his intentions bent to have his wife naught, which the wickede≈øt man that ever I heard of before would have vertuous, and godly, how bad ≈øoever him≈øelfe be, and him lewd to his owne wife, if ≈øhe love him ≈øhe mu≈øt love Henry Skipwith, whom he loves above all, and not in any hone≈øt love, but in a di≈øhone≈øt; he gives his rea≈øon by Scripture, ≈øhe was now ≈øubject to him, and therefore if ≈øhe did ill at his command it was not her fault but his, and he would an≈øwer it; he lets this Skipwith who he calls his favourite, ≈øpend of his pur≈øe 500. l'. per annum, and if his wife or daughter would have any thing, though nece≈ø≈øary, they mu≈øt lie with Skipwith and have it from him, and not otherwi≈øe; al≈øo telling Skipwith and his daughter, that he had rather have a child by him then by any body el≈øe. But this thing I had rather ≈øhould come out of the mouthes of the witne≈ø≈øes then from me.

div.head: The ≈øeverall Examinations and Depo≈øitions before the Lords.
Walter Bigges Examination.
div.p: ANtill was a Page to Sir Henry Smith, and had no meanes when he came to my Lord Audley: he entertained him for a Page eight yeares, and then let him keepe hor≈øes in his ground, by which I thinke he inriched him≈øelfe 2000 .l'. but he never ≈øat at the table with him till he had married his daughter, then gave him to the value of 7000 .l'. Henry Skipwith, was ≈øent from Ireland by my Lord, to be a Page to my Lady, his Father and Mother were very meane folkes, there he ≈øpent out of my Lords meanes 500 .l'. per annum, and he gave him at one time 1000 .l'. and hath made divers deeds of lands to him: My Lord was at fir≈øt a Prote≈øtant, after the buying of Fountaine turn'd his religion.

div.head: Lord Audley his Examination.
div.p: HE ≈øaith Henry Skipwith had no meanes when hee came to him, and that he had given him 1000 .l'. and that Skipwith did lie with him when he was ≈øtraightned in roome; and that hee gave a farme of 100 .l'. to Antil that married his daughter, and at other times to the valew of 7000 .l'. and that there was one Blawdma in his hou≈øe 14. daies, and be≈øtowed an ill di≈øea≈øe there, and therefore he ≈øent her away.
Lord high Steward ≈øaid, I advi≈øe you not to deny tho≈øe things which are cloerly proved, for then the Lords will give le≈ø≈øe credit to the re≈øt you ≈øay.

div.head: The Counte≈ø≈øes examination.
div.p: THe fir≈øt or ≈øecond night after we were married, Antil came to his bed ≈øide while≈øt we were in bed, and the Lord ≈øpake la≈øciviou≈øly to her, and told her, her body was his, and that if ≈øhe loved him, ≈øhee mu≈øt love Antil, and if ≈øhee lay with any man with his con≈øent, it was not her fault, but his.

Hee would make Skipwith come naked into her chamber, and bed, and delighted in calling up his ≈øervants, making them ≈øhew their privities, and her looke on, and commended tho≈øe that had the large≈øt.

Broadway lay with her whil≈øt ≈øhe made re≈øi≈øtance, and my Lord held her hands, and one of her feet, and ≈øhe would have killed her ≈øelfe afterwards with a knife, but that hee tooke it from her: and before that act of Broadway ≈øhee had never done it. He delighted to ≈øee the act done, and made Antil come into the bed to them, and lye with her whil≈øt he might ≈øee it; and that ≈øhe cryed out.

div.head: Fitz Patricks examination.
div.p: THat Henry Skipwith was the ≈øpeciall favourite of the Lord, and that he u≈øually lay with him; and that Skipwith ≈øayd, the Lord made him lye with his owne Lady Awdley, and that he ≈øaw Skipwith in his ≈øight doe it, my Lord being pre≈øent; and that he lay with Blaudma in his ≈øight, and foure more, and afterwards he him≈øelfe in their ≈øights.

div.head: Henry Skipwiths examination.
div.p:
HE ≈øpent five hundred pounds per annum of the Lords pur≈øe. He lay for the mo≈øt part in bed with the Earle: hee gave him his hou≈øe in Salisbury, and a Mannour of a hundred and three≈øeore pound per annum; and that hee u≈øually lay with the young Lady, and there was love before and afterwards. And that my Lord ≈øaid hee would rather have a boy of his getting, then of any other; and that ≈øhee was but thirteene yeares old
when he lay with her, and that hee could not enter her body without art; and that my Lord gave her things to open her. That Blawdma lived halfe a yeere in my Lords hou≈øe, and was a common whore.

div.head: Fitz Patricks examination.
div.p: THe Lord made him lye with him at Fountaine, and Sali≈øbury, and once in the bed, & ≈øemen con≈øump≈øit but did not penetrate his body; and that hee heard he did-≈øo with others. That Skipwith lay with the young Lady often, and that the Lord would have a boy by him; that Blawdma lived halfe a yeare in the Lords hou≈øe, and was a common whore.

div.head: Friers examination.
div.p: THat Henry Skipwith and the Lady lay together, and that he would faine have a boy by him.

div.head: The young Lady Audleyes examination.
div.p: THat ≈øhe was married to her husband by a Romi≈øh Prie≈øt in the morning, and at night by a Prebend of Kelkenny: that ≈øhee was fir≈øt tempted to lye with Skipwith by the Earle of Ca≈øtlehaven, and that ≈øhe had no meanes but that which Skipwith gave her; but ≈øhe would not lye with Pawlet: he ≈øolicited al≈øo to lye with Greene: that hee ≈øaw Skipwith and ≈øhee lye together divers times, and nine of the ≈øervants in the hou≈øe had likewi≈øe ≈øeene it.

When he ≈øolicited her ≈øhe ≈øaid her husband loved her not, and that he would turne her out of doores if ≈øhe did not, and if ≈øhe would not he would tell her husband ≈øhe did. That he u≈øed a wyld to enter her body fir≈øt: that he u≈øually lay with her, and it was with the Earles priviry.

div.head: Broadwayes examination.
div.p:
HE lay at the beds feet, and in the night he called for Tobacco, and as he brought it, caught him, and bid him come to bed to him and his wife, and held one of his wives
legs, and both her hands, and at la≈øt he lay with her, notwith≈øtanding her re≈øi≈øtance.
That he u≈øed his body like a woman, ≈øed nunquam penetravit, quamvis inter femine, ≈øemen ≈øuum con≈øump≈øit.

He hath ≈øeene Skipwith and the young Lady lye together in bed, and when he got upon her, the Lord hath ≈øtood by and encouraged him to get her with childe, and made him ki≈ø≈øe his Lady, and lye with her, telling him he ≈øhould not live long, and it might be his making; and he ≈øaid to Skipwith the like.

div.head: The Counte≈ø≈øes examination.
div.p: AT Fountaine the Lord brought Broadway to bed, and hee held her hands and one of her feet, whil≈øt Broadway lay with her: and that ≈øhe caught a knife, and would have killed her ≈øelfe, but that they tooke it from her.

div.head: The Earles examination.
div.p: HEE de≈øired to bee pardoned in tho≈øe things of which hee mu≈øt accu≈øe him≈øelfe, and that condemnation ≈øhould not come out of his owne mouth.

Ma≈øter Attorney generall ≈øaid, you have ≈øeene the cleernes of the cau≈øe proved, and I know your wi≈øedomes to be ≈øuch as you well know in ≈øo darke a bu≈øine≈ø≈øe a clearer cannot be; for let a man be never ≈øo wicked, he will not call witne≈ø≈øes to ≈øee it.
Lord high Steward asked, whether may a wife be witne≈ø≈øe again≈øt her husband.
Judges an≈øwer: In civill cau≈øes ≈øhe cannot, in criminall ≈øhee may, e≈øpecially where ≈øhe is the party grieved.
Lord high Steward asked whether buggery was within the Statute, without penetration.
Judges an≈øwer: It may, the u≈øe of the body to ≈øpend ≈øeed doth it.
Lord high Steward asked whether one can ravi≈øh a woman of ill fame, or no.
Judges an≈øwer: a whore may be ravi≈øhed, and it is felony to doe it. Lord high Steward asked whether there be a nece≈ø≈øity of accu≈øation for ravi≈øhing, in convenient time.
Judges an≈øwer: in an indictment there is not, in an appea≈øe there is.
Lord high Steward asked, whether men of no worth ≈øhall be ≈øufficient proofe again≈øt a Baron.
Judges an≈øwer: any man in felony.

Then the Lords went away to con≈øider, and after their returne the Lord Steward asked one by one, fir≈øt of the indictment of rape, to which they all an≈øwered, Guilty; then to the other, and fifteene found him guilty, and the re≈øt not.

Lord Audley ≈øpake for him≈øelfe, that his wife had beene naught, and had a childe, which hee concealed to ≈øave her honour, and that his ≈øon now became 21. yeares of age, and hee old, that the one would have lands, the other a younger hu≈øband, and therefore they plotted his death.
Then the Lieutenant was called to bring out the pri≈øoner, who when he was come to the Barre, the Lord high Steward ≈øpake to him in this manner.
